fields.description:
AWS enforced a limit 2 access keys per user:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/LimitationsOnEntities.html

When no limit is enforced by the system, users might end up creating a large number of active long-term credentials which creates a security risk to the whole system. There is no need for a user to have more than 2 access keys at a time.
fields.summary: Limit of 2 access keys and signing certs per user should be enforced

comments.body: To address this issue we should enforce limits for access keys and signing certificates. The credential download servlet should be updated to allow for these limits (currently a signing certificate is generated for each credential download)

Example of limit errors with euca2ools:

{code}
# euare-useraddkey
euare-useraddkey: error (LimitExceeded): Access key limit exceeded
#
#
# euare-usercreatecert -u admin
euare-usercreatecert: error (LimitExceeded): Signing certificate limit exceeded
{code}

Cloud properties are added to configure the limits for access keys and signing certificates:

* authentication.access_keys_limit
* authentication.signing_certificates_limit

the default limit is 2.

Credential download will fail if there are no active access keys for a user and the limit would be exceeded by creating a new key. If the user does not have a signing certificate one will be created and included in the downloaded credentials. If the user already has a signing certificate then one is not included in the downloaded credentials.

Limits do not apply to the "eucalyptus" account.
[~sjones], why the limits do not apply to the "eucalyptus" account? It makes sense to enforce it for all accounts.

[~rusvika], if the limit(s) applied to the "eucalyptus" account then I think we would need a new mechanism to allow recovery if existing access keys were somehow disabled. In that case there would be no more keys permitted, and no working keys to put in the credential download. The limit is also implemented as an IAM quota and these do not currently apply to the "eucalyptus" account. In the longer term we're moving away from direct use of the "eucalyptus" account, so it is also less important from that perspective.
Hmm, the limit for the eucalyptus account could be soft (enforced unless the admin forces to exceed it), it's still better than no limit. Lets discuss it more on an arch meeting.

Could we ad to the key limit message the following please, for console users or folks that don't have policies in place to delete or deactivate keys?

error (LimitExceeded): Access key limit exceeded. Please delete unused keys or contact your cloud administrator.
[~jloza], I'm not sure the cloud administrator would be the appropriate one to resolve the issue, did you mean the account administrator?

Reopening to apply limit to eucalyptus account also. We'll add a special case for downloads with the eucalyptus account and modify the euca-get-credentials command to allow the access key limit to be overridden (to avoid any possibility of lock-out)

hi [~sjones], in the console we usually refer to "cloud administrator" in messages even for login issues and things the account admin persona would technically solve. We do this because users will not really know about the persona-based delineations we have in place, and which persona is responsible for what actions, but they do understand "cloud admin" and will know who they should be talking to when we say that. For a user, that phrase is more generic, and can apply to whomever they have been in contact with w/r/t their cloud account. 

Make sense to you? Please let me know your thoughts...
As administrative roles (personas are a design concept; roles are the actual things) are part of the cloud administrator's account, the term "cloud admin" should cover those just fine as well.

[~jloza], as the error message has a console specific interpretation it seems best to define the error message in the console rather than to change the message the service is sending (this should be simple to do by checking the error code "LimitExceeded")

I believe [~sjones] means the actual admin for the user's account, not a privileged persona. Any account admin has privileges to manage keys for users in this account and there is no need to escalate to the cloud admin.

[~rusvika], yep that is why the console uses terms like cloud admin, because it's more generic. 

[~sjones], the console displays the error messages exactly as returned by the back end, that's why it would be helpful to have that clause added. It won't hurt anyone else who sees it either, just getting bases covered.

[~jloza], I think it would be a bit confusing for the service to return the requested error message for those who were familiar with AWS accounts/users and credentials. I'll be pushing changes for this issue shortly so please open a separate issue for the error message if it cannot be handled on the console.

We now check limits for the eucalyptus account (and other system accounts) and there is a new '--force' option for use with 'euca-get-credentials' that disables the limit (as was requested)

EUCA-10005 is added to enable the limit checking on credential downloads once QA is updated.

With this change are we expecting to not see {{EC2_CERT}} and {{EC2_PRIVATE_KEY}} in eucarc after cloud credentials are downloaded? As a cloud administrator after setting up a fresh 4.1 cloud and downloading my creds I could not upload the 1st image to the cloud because of no signing certificate available to me, this is a change from previous version where the signining certificate was available to me along with the creds (when downloaded). 

Trying to understand the implications of the changes done here and if any documentation work is required as well to make sure our users know about it.
[~dshekhawat], the signing certificate credentials are omitted from the downloaded credentials in some cases, see EUCA-10273 for further details of the configuration options around this behaviour.

Thanks [~sjones] for more insight on this issue.

I can confirm that in 4.1.0 we do not allow more than 2 access keys and signing certs by default. However one can modify the cloud property to increase the default limit. In order to verify this issue I create 2 users in 1 account and tried to create access keys and signing certs for them using {{euare-useraddkey}} and {{euare-useraddcert}} respectively.

{code}
# euare-useraddkey -u deependra --as-account=support
euare-useraddkey: error (LimitExceeded): Access key limit exceeded
{code}

{code}
# euare-useraddcert -u deependra --as-account=support -f /root/support/admin/myeuca-cert.pem
euare-useraddcert: error (LimitExceeded): Signing certificate limit exceeded
{code}

Packages used to confirm the fix were:

{code}
# rpm -qa | grep euca
eucalyptus-4.1.0-0.0.22958.317.20150108git00561e8.el6.x86_64
eucanetd-4.1.0-0.0.22958.317.20150108git00561e8.el6.x86_64
eucalyptus-admin-tools-4.1.0-0.0.22958.317.20150108git00561e8.el6.noarch
eucalyptus-cloud-4.1.0-0.0.22958.317.20150108git00561e8.el6.x86_64
eucalyptus-common-java-libs-4.1.0-0.0.22958.317.20150108git00561e8.el6.x86_64
eucalyptus-common-java-4.1.0-0.0.22958.317.20150108git00561e8.el6.x86_64
euca2ools-3.2.0-0.0.1640.14.20150108git94c0859.el6.noarch
{code}
Fix Verified. Thanks [~dshekhawat]!
